awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF The contributions of composition and length-scale to the peak strength of the lithosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Kathryn Kumamoto has been awarded a postdoctoral fellowship to engage in research and education at the University of Oxford, in the UK. The theory of plate tectonics describes a set of stable, rigid plates (the lithosphere) moving on top of a comparatively soft convecting medium (the asthenosphere). The strength of the lithosphere compared to the asthenosphere determines how the plates interact and is likely responsible for differences in tectonic styles between Earth, Mars, and Venus. However, laboratory measurements of olivine, the most abundant mineral in the oceanic lithosphere, indicate its strength is significantly greater than plate strengths inferred from field observations and numerical simulations of plate tectonics. This stark disagreement inhibits the creation of predictive models for large-scale phenomena like the formation of new plate boundaries, the uplift of Earth's surface after removing ice sheets, and the stress evolution of seismogenic faults after an earthquake. This project will use experiments to investigate three mechanisms that may lead to a weaker lithospheric mantle than predicted by current laboratory data: a length-scale effect (manifesting in terms of grain size), the presence of intracrystalline water, and the role of secondary mantle phases (orthopyroxene and clinopyroxene). The education plan focuses on (1) co-teaching undergraduate tutorials on rock deformation, incorporating modern research techniques into the curriculum, and (2) teaching an earth science course in an outreach summer school aimed at the high school level. 

Deformation experiments will be conducted using state-of-the-art interdisciplinary techniques, including nanoindentation and D-DIA to deform plastically natural samples in the laboratory. The PI will establish the plastic behavior of olivine, orthopyroxene, and clinopyroxene at room temperature while varying the length-scale and water content of the experiments. Deformed samples will be characterized using secondary ion mass spectrometry to measure water concentrations and high-angular resolution electron backscatter diffraction to determine the microstructures related to crystal deformation. Experiments will then be conducted at high temperatures to develop low-temperature plasticity flow laws for the three minerals. Finally, the behavior of multi-phase aggregates will be examined to determine the best method for combining monomineralic flow laws to understand the strength of tectonic plates. The results of this project will provide constitutive constraints that can be incorporated into models of mantle convection, plate flexure, and deformation at the base of the seismogenic zone. Broader impacts include methodology development: setting up NanoSIMS to measure water content in samples as well as HR-EBSD for pyroxeme minerals. The interdisciplinary nature of this project may provide new perspectives on Earth materials deformation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The rheology (or flow) of the lithospheric mantle (the portion of Earth's mantle that forms the majority of tectonic plates) plays a central role in processes such as deep earthquakes, the formation of new tectonic plate boundaries, and plate flexure at subduction zones. However, at the comparatively low temperatures associated with this portion of the mantle, previous experiments on olivine, the dominant mineral in the upper mantle, were in disagreement, both with each other and with observations of Earth. This project sought to resolve these discrepancies by investigating the strength of the lithospheric mantle using carefully controlled experiments on its three main constituent minerals: olivine, orthopyroxene, and clinopyroxene.

In particular the goals of this project were to:
1. Constrain the effects of grain size and trace concentrations of water on mineral strength,
2. Develop flow laws describing mineral strength at low temperatures, and
3. Explore how the strength of rocks containing multiple minerals compare to the behavior of their constituent minerals.

Hansen et al. (2019, Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth) examined olivine plasticity using deformation experiments on a synchrotron beamline at the Advanced Photon Source of Argonne National Laboratory. The results of room-temperature experiments on olivine with different grain sizes demonstrated that yield stress, or the stress where permanent deformation begins, is inversely correlated with the grain size of the sample. In addition, this study identified both strain hardening, where a material gets stronger as it is deformed, and a Bauschinger effect, where the yield stress of a material decreases when the direction of deformation is reversed. From these results, a flow law describing the relationship between grain size, strain hardening, stress, and strain rate was developed. Importantly, including the effects of grain size and strain hardening on olivine strength resolves many discrepancies between previous experiments. Wallis et al. (2020, Earth and Planetary Science Letters) examined the microstructures of these same experiments and linked the Bauschinger effect to the distribution of crystal defects in the samples.

The effect of trace concentrations of water dissolved as H+ ions in the crystal structure of olivine was examined using nanoindentation experiments. While water has a large effect on olivine's strength at elevated temperatures, with tens of parts per million decreasing viscosity by orders of magnitude, the yield strength of water-bearing olivine at room temperature was nearly indistinguishable from that of dry olivine. This puts constraints on the mechanisms by which water could affect mineral strength.

Room-temperature nanoindentation experiments were also performed on orthopyroxene and clinopyroxene single crystals. Both minerals were very similar to olivine in their mechanical response. Similarities amongst silicate minerals were also identified in Thom et al. (in revision), where the normalized relationship between measured strain hardening and defect concentrations derived from geometry was the same for olivine, quartz, and plagioclase. This suggests that similar processes and mechanisms control the strength of all these silicate minerals at room temperature, even though their high-temperature properties are very different.

A series of experiments on rocks containing different amounts of olivine and orthopyroxene was performed at the Advanced Photon Source to determine how the strength of these two-phase rocks compared to a rock composed only of olivine. Results indicate that up to temperatures of 600 degrees Celsius, the yield stress of olivine-orthopyroxene mixtures was the same as the yield stress of olivine within error. However, orthopyroxene-bearing mixtures deformed at a slower rate than olivine-only samples, and the magnitude of this difference increased with both temperature and orthopyroxene content. This suggests that using an olivine flow law to describe low-temperature deformation in the Earth's mantle may predict the correct yield stress but will overestimate the rate at which deformation occurs. 

This fellowship facilitated many opportunities for professional development, with some highlights mentioned here. Work led by the PI at the Advanced Photon Source was done in collaboration with graduate students, post-docs, and professors from 8 academic institutions and will contribute to 3 Ph.D. theses. The PI also cosupervises two Ph.D. students in Earth Sciences at the University of Oxford, both of whom have participated in synchrotron experiments and presented related work at conferences. In addition, the PI took over the day-to-day management of the Rock Rheology Laboratory in Earth Sciences, preparing her for managing her own laboratory in the future.
